Chapter 1, section 5 on the five kinds of eloquence, the first part on the main points. The elder says:
The fire element, whether small or not increasing in strength, is called cold.
Why is it so?
Because when there is no sun or it is far from the sun, there is cold.
Moreover, when extremely great heat arises, it is not admitted that there is the arising of a separate small part of derivative contact, but only that the fire element increases greatly;

when heat decreases, it should be the same. It should be admitted that there is the arising of a separate small part of derivative contact, but it should be admitted that only the fire element decreases.

If there is a separate cold, it should also be admitted that there is a separate derivative contact that is neither hot nor cold. Therefore, there is definitely no derivative contact of cold. The fire element, whether small or not increasing in strength, is called cold.
It is seen that when the fire element increases in one who is harmed by cold contact, it can benefit.
Who with intelligence would hold that one who is harmed by a small fire should be thrown into a great fire?
If you say that he is harmed because of a lack of fire, this is not reasonable, because there must be another cause of harm.
That is, because of the small amount of fire, the other cold increases and can harm him, not the fire itself.

On the basis of this, we conclude that when cold benefits, it is a small cause, and when the benefited person is benefited, if this cause increases, it should benefit. Therefore the treatise is not reasonable.

Also, what they say, that when heat increases or decreases, there is no derivative form produced, and it is only fire, is also unreasonable, because we see that two dharmas that are mutually contradictory may increase or decrease.

For example, when the path of insight that eliminates the passions increases, no other passions are produced. In the same way, when the path of cultivation that eliminates the passions increases, no other passions are produced.
Also, when cold is born, it is born from the combination of the other elements, i.e., water and wind, and not from fire. Therefore, it is not proper to raise the question of the increase of fire.
Also, if you maintain that a small amount of fire is cold, then in a mass of snow the fire element is extremely small and should be colder than cold.
You should not say that as the fire element gradually diminishes,
so does the fire element increase. This is the correct theory.
They maintain that cold is not a separate substance from fire, and that when there is little fire it is not fire.
Therefore there is a separate substance that is different from the four great elements. When the fire element diminishes, the substance increases, and the derivative touch is called cold.

There is another interpretation of this theory, namely, that the cold touch is produced by the increase of the great elements, and that the cold touch is the great elements themselves. This is also unreasonable, because cold is different from the characteristics of water and wind.

Also, if it were composed of two substances, its substance would be a nominal one, and it would not be the object of the body consciousness, because there is no separate nature apart from cold and heat.
The example of the absence of a separate cold is not the same as this, because cold, etc., are the lower categories of heat, etc., and differ in their states.
Other masters say,
that cold, etc., only use heat, etc., as their substance.
This is also not so, because their categories are different, just as heat, etc., do not allow the existence of a category of nonexisting things.

Or, earth, etc., would use nonexisting natures, because one can also say that the only water, etc., that exist are called the realms of earth, etc. Therefore what they say is not a reason for the nonexistence of cold as a derivative form.

Also, because cold can be a condition for the generation of sensation, just as the realm of fire, etc., are not just heat, there would be no fire at all in a mass of form, and it is not reasonable to say that it both exists and does not exist.
Since there must be fire in all masses of form, then cold sensation would be absolutely nonexistent. Therefore we know that apart from fire there is a separate cold sensation.
Moreover, cold touch really exists, its characteristics are distinct, and it can be directly perceived, just like heat and so forth.
Moreover, because it is mentioned in the scriptures like heat, its substance must exist. A scripture says:
I can endure both cold and heat. If at that time cold and heat are moderate, then one can mature, attain, and accomplish. At that time, it is neither extremely cold nor extremely hot.
If it is extremely cold or hot, one cannot cultivate. Therefore, the existence of cold derivative form is established.
Moreover, the elder says:
Hunger and thirst are not derivative form because they are the nature of desire.
This is also unreasonable, because these two are called effects in terms of their causes.
Due to the difference in contact that oppresses the body, the desire for food and drink arises. This is the cause of hunger and thirst, and therefore it is called hunger and thirst.
It is like speaking of serenity, which is the lightness of the body, because it is the effect of serenity, it is called serenity.
If this is so, then the cause of desire should be heat, because the heat of the fire element can cook and digest food and drink, and thus generates the desire for food and drink.
This argument is unreasonable, because the two desires for food and drink should be derivative form, because fire is their cause.
Moreover, the fire element is not the cause of the two desires, because it should generate desire at all times.

It is seen that the two desires do not exist at all times. How is it that the cause of desire is the great elements that support the derivative form of touch, which, although always existing, are not nonexistent, but the substance of the derivative form of touch is not always present?
This example is not appropriate, because the cause of desire, the derivative form of touch, must wait for the increase of the wind and fire elements in order to be born.
If you say that the two desires are also like this, this is not reasonable, because, as stated previously, the two desires should be by nature derivative form.
If you say that just as the great elements that are touched generate the body consciousness, and yet the body consciousness is not by nature derivative form, so also is desire,ğŸ”½this is not so.

This is not similar, because consciousness does not necessarily arise due to the increase of the great elements. Desire is not so, because it arises due to increase. Therefore, the body consciousness is not caused by the great elements.
Or it arises with equality or increase, but only according to the support, not due to distinction.
It arises due to the body and touch as conditions, but the two desires are not so, like derivative form.
It must arise due to the increase of the great elements.
Since it arises according to the distinction of the great elements, why is it prevented from being derivative form?

If wind and fire increase, the two desires increase. If wind and fire diminish, the two desires diminish. Since they do not equally increase or diminish according to the great elements, why are the two desires not the nature of derivative form?

If it is said that although the two desires are caused by the great elements, they do not rely on them, so they are not derivative form, and that desire relies on the mind but not on the great elements, so it should not be argued that they become derivative form.
If so, then these desires should not necessarily arise due to the increase of the great elements.
We do not see that the body consciousness does not depend on the great elements, but arises according to the differences in the great elements.
We only see that the body consciousness takes the great elements as its condition, and when they are equal or increased, only the tactile object arises.

If this is so, then the two desires should always arise without waiting for the increase of their causes, and the previously stated difficulty that the two desires are difficult to maintain and difficult to eliminate should always arise.
Moreover, even when the wind and fire elements sometimes increase, the two desires for food and drink do not arise. Therefore we know that the two desires do not arise due to the present [elements].
What is the reason that their causes do not arise at that time?
Because the supported body has a fault, or because it is obstructed by other conditions.
Isn't it precisely because of this that the two desires do not arise? What need is there to further imagine that there is a cause for desire that produces the tactile object?
This is not so, because desire arises simultaneously with body consciousness. Even though there is obstruction, consciousness can arise while desire cannot arise.
What is the principle here?
The arising of mental factors is definitely dependent on support, object, and the combination of consciousness.
Moreover, it seeks the stage of great dharmas, and therefore arises together with all mental states.
The dominant conditions for the arising of desire exist at that time, but if it does not arise, it is definitely hindered by other conditions for arising.
The other conditions are the derivative form called touch.
Therefore, apart from the great elements, there is a real hunger and thirst, which have derivative form as their nature.

Moreover, one should not say that the obstruction to the arising of derivative form is the same as the obstruction to mind and mental factors, lest the obstruction to the arising of mind, etc. be the same as the obstruction to the arising of derivative form, because there is no different cause.
Let us stop this extensive dispute for now. One must believe that hunger and thirst have derivative form as their nature.
Now we should consider:
If the great elements increase in a mass of form, is it in substance or in function?
What is the reason for further encouraging such consideration?
In order to remove unreal faults.

We do not know what the author of the treatise intends here, who is determined to be the VaibhÄá¹£ika?

If one grasps that solidity, etc. are equal and without difference, by what cause can one obtain the separate concepts of earth, etc.?
If you say that the cause is the function, this is not so, because the function is not different from the substance.
If the function is real, then the substance increases and becomes real, because the function is identical with the substance.
If the function is not real, then the substance increases and becomes unreal, because the function is not different from the substance.

This is the general explanation. However, there is a difference, because the four great material elements are resistant and can be accumulated, and their differences of location and position are clearly evident.
Sensation, etc., are not resistant and cannot be accumulated. They are only distinguished by function, and their increase or decrease is known by their differences.

This is not contradictory, because although the touch of vinegar and water is equal in subtlety, their tastes are not the same. The subtlety of the taste of vinegar is greater, while the subtlety of the taste of water is less. Therefore, the superiority of the taste of vinegar still results from the increase in substance.
In various aggregates, substances such as taste have a stronger substance, and therefore they have an increased function.
The principle of the conditioned arising of good medicine, poison, etc. is different, and therefore their substance and type are like this.

Because of this, although they are few, they can subdue many. They are not born with a different substance and type having a separate function. Therefore, the attachment to increased function is a mistaken theory.
Or, just as the categories are different, the individual items are also like this. Therefore, only mind, etc. are said to increase in terms of function.
Increasing in terms of substance refers to the various dharmas of form, just as many are accomplished by relying on one.
Moreover, the various great elements are said to increase in terms of substance because they can be directly perceived, because of the teachings, and because of principle.
That is, when the primary elements increase, their substance can be obtained, not their function or activity, because they have aggregation and obstruction.
The teaching refers to the Sutra on the Simile of Seeds, which states:
If there is an earth element without a water element, they should not aggregate, because there is no ability to attract.
In this way, it is explained in detail in the sutra one by one.
The meaning of this sutra is that there is no aggregate of form that completely lacks the water element. If it completely lacked it, it should not be combined.
However, there are aggregates of form that cannot attract and combine other forms, because they are small.
The other elements should be understood in the same way.

Reasoning means that if the primary elements only increase in function, not in substance or aggregation, and are said to increase, then there should be primary elements or derivative form in a single atom that also increases in function.
Just as in the substance of a single dharma such as feeling, sometimes the function increases and it alone can be the object. Why do the atoms each abide separately?
They cannot be the object to produce the five sense consciousnesses.

Moreover, if the most subtle atoms have a strong function, their characteristics should be coarse and obvious, and they should not be the most subtle. Therefore, the substance of material dharmas is said to increase in terms of their ability to accumulate and their substantial obstruction.
The substance of immaterial dharmas cannot accumulate and is not substantially obstructed, so their function is said to increase.
This meaning is already established and cannot be shaken.

Moreover, it should now be said:
What is the reason that solidity, etc. are the basis of form?
It is not the other forms, etc., because this pervades all places.
That is to say, in all aggregates, the four characteristics of earth, etc. are all present, but form, etc. are not so. For this reason, earth, etc. are established by three meanings:
The meaning of basis, the meaning of ability to produce, and the meaning of vastness.
Moreover, because they are what form, etc. follow.

We see in the world that when such things as pots and pans are matured by fire, their color, etc., undergo transformation, because there is a difference in striking, beating, and rubbing, and sound undergoes transformation and is produced.
The other dharmas such as color, etc., do not have this.

Also, because it can destroy other material objects, color, etc., have no function of support in earth.
If this is so, then the sense organs should not be destroyed by a long-lasting color such as snow.
No, because the support of that color can destroy the support of the sense organs.

Because we are aware of the suffering produced by it in the dark, we know that it only destroys the primary elements and not the sense organs. If it destroyed the sense organs, we should not be aware of the production of body consciousness.
Also, color cannot destroy the primary elements, because it is not tangible.
Therefore, only the primary elements can destroy other material objects, and therefore they are the support of color, and not the other dharmas such as color, etc.
Some say:
Because the nature of solidity, etc., is that which is contacted by the body, it can serve as the basis of the body consciousness.
This explanation is unreasonable, because cold, etc., should be the nature of the great elements.
However, cold, etc., are not pervasive, and therefore they cannot be the great elements.
Isn't it the case that there is no cold touch in warmth, and also no warmth in cold touch? Warmth should be like cold and also not a great element.
This objection is not valid, because cold has warmth, but it is not perceived due to being covered by cold.
If that is so, then cold touch should be pervasive like warmth.
No, because the function of cold does not exist in warmth. The function of warmth can be obtained in cold, but the function of cold cannot be obtained in warmth.
The objection that cold is pervasive like warmth should be stopped.
What is the function of warmth?
It is called maturation.
Isn't it seen that cold can also mature? Because things do not rot due to having warmth, the cause of not rotting is called maturation;
cold is also like this, and should be the same as warmth.

This is also unreasonable, because the water and wind elements are predominant, temporarily congealing, and the maturation here is precisely the function of heat. Therefore, it should not be said that the nature of the tangibility of solidity, etc. can serve as the basis, because cold, etc. should be the nature of the great elements.
However, that cold tangibility is the result of the predominance of the water and wind elements, and is therefore a derivative form.
Moreover, that cold tangibility cannot be found to have the four definite functions of supporting, containing, maturing, and expanding, and therefore its substance is not a great element.
How is it that snow, etc. do not have a superior function due to congealing from cold?
This statement is unreasonable, because the predominance of the water and wind elements gives rise to the cold tangibility as its result.
It is also due to heat that the juice of sugarcane, etc. can be congealed.
If it is said that cold is the result of the great elements, then cold and heat would be mutually contradictory and should not be combined. How then could cold arise from heat?

Just as solidity and moisture are the same substance, so they do not mutually contradict each other. Water and fire are also like this. Since they are the same substance, there is no contradiction in principle.

Just as cold water is poured on quicklime, heat is produced from the cold. This should also be so. Since the great elements are the same substance, even though they are mutually contradictory, they are always combined.
Cold is the effect that is produced by water and wind. The earth element does not contradict them at all.
Even though the nature of fire contradicts them, it does not cause harm, because they are the same effect. Why would it prevent their combination?

Moreover, if one sees that because those elements increase, in those aggregates a different great element is established, then those elements are the cause that produces and nourishes the derivative form, and are called the great elements.
It is not because the increase of cold establishes a different great element in those aggregates, so it is not a great element.
However, because heat increases, in those aggregates the notion of a different great element ceases and the notion of a different great element arises.
Cold is not like this. Therefore, cold and warmth are different natures of the supported and the support.

This difficulty is like the previous explanation that water and wind increase and generate cold touch and produce them as results.
Or ice, snow, and hail are different names for water, not like grass, trees, etc., which are different names for fire. Therefore, the difficulty they raise is definitely not the same.
Therefore, cold touch is only a derivative nature. For this reason, the realm of touch has two meanings.
The remaining nine form realms are only derivative, namely the five form faculties, form, sound, smell, and taste. One part of the dharma realm is also only derivative.
What is this again?
It is said to be derivative because unmanifested action arises in dependence on the great elements.

The remaining seven mind realms and one part of the dharma realm, excluding unmanifested form, are neither of the two kinds. The meaning is established by implication.

Or, in citing the element of space, it represents the other derivative form. Therefore, in citing this scripture, it does not deny derivative form.

How do they establish the distinction between object and possessor of an object?

If a person touches his own body, since he grasps both the body and the contact as having the same characteristic, in a single moment they are mutually undifferentiated. How can one be established as the object and the other as the possessor of the object?
If there is a difference, the meaning of different natures is established.

That is, what is contacted, such as hardness, etc., is called the object, and the body that is contrary to this is called the possessor of the object, because it is admitted that the nature of the body and contact is different.
If there is no difference, then there is no establishment of the distinction between object and possessor of an object, and this contradicts both reason and the teachings.

If it is said that, just as the mind, although having the same characteristic, in a single moment establishes the object and the possessor of the object without contradiction, this is also unreasonable, because although the mind is the object, it is always established as the possessor of the object, so there is no such error.

However, the object of the body faculty, such as the great elements of hardness, etc., is never at any time established as the possessor of the object, so the analogy of the mind as a savior is extremely unequal.
If you admit that the body faculty and its object, the four great elements of solidity, etc., are also objects, what is wrong with that?

If this is so, then the body faculty should be established as only one sense base, and then there would be no definite establishment of this as the body sense base and that as the sense base of touch.
You must explain what definite principle there is to determine that this is only an object and that is only a faculty.

Moreover, if form, etc., are the four great elements, then the blue color of each atom is the four great elements, or it is only one, and both are erroneous.

However, although form, etc., are the same in being called form, there are differences in the characteristics of blue, yellow, fragrance, sweetness, coldness, etc. Consequently, the five objects are different from each other. There is no error of the five sense faculties such as the eye having a common object.
If the four great elements have different characteristics and are not different in substance from the blue atom, then how can they not be established as four natures because they are one?
If a single atom of blue has only one great element, then the four great elements would be mutually separated, because a single aggregate would have only one great element.
This would contradict the sutra that uses the analogy of seeds, and the great elements of different natures would not be able to form without distinction.

If it is said to be the earth element, then ponds, pools, rivers, and seas should not have blue color.
If it is said to be the water element, then jade, blue stones, etc. should not be extremely blue.
If it is said to be the fire element, then the world's raging fire should not be extremely red.
If it is said to be the wind element, then color should not be unobtainable in the wind.

If it is said that the color blue is different from the great elements, and that there is a single substance that increases with one of the realms, and that many great elements each produce blue color to form a single aggregate, there is no contradiction in principle. Therefore there is derivative form that is produced by the great elements.
There is also clear and definite scriptural authority, as stated in the sutra:
All forms are included in the four great elements and the four great elements that are derivative.
What reason is there to know that the word derivative has a different meaning from the great elements and refers to something else?
However, a scripture says:
There are ignorant people who experience pleasure or pain through the six sense bases, or who experience one of them through what is derived from them.
